Literature Review: The study of ancient Indian Ocean connections has been a subject of increasing interest among archaeologists in recent years. This literature review focuses on the archaeological contributions to our understanding of long-distance interregional connections across the Indian Ocean from 500 BCE to 1000 CE. The period under consideration witnessed significant developments in maritime trade, cultural exchange, and technological advancements that shaped the complex networks spanning this vast oceanic region.One of the most significant areas of research has been the study of ceramic evidence. Tomber's comprehensive work on Roman and Indian trade ceramics has provided valuable insights into the nature and extent of maritime connections between the Mediterranean and the Indian subcontinent (Tomber, 2008). The analysis of amphorae and fine wares has allowed researchers to trace trade routes and identify key ports of exchange. Building on this foundation, Seland's study of Red Sea trade networks has further illuminated the intricate web of connections linking the Roman world with South Asia and beyond (Seland, 2014).Beads have emerged as another crucial category of material evidence for understanding long-distance connections. Francis's seminal work on bead trade in the Indian Ocean region has demonstrated the significance of these small artifacts in tracing cultural and economic interactions (Francis, 2002). More recently, Carter's research on carnelian beads has provided new insights into the production and distribution networks of this prized material, highlighting the role of Gujarat as a major center of bead manufacturing and export (Carter, 2015).The application of advanced scientific techniques has revolutionized the study of ancient Indian Ocean trade. Lankton and Dussubieux's use of laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) to analyze glass beads has allowed for more precise identification of production centers and trade patterns (Lankton and Dussubieux, 2006). This approach has been further developed by Pion and Gratuze, who have used similar techniques to study the composition and provenance of glass artifacts found in Southeast Asian contexts, shedding light on the extent of Indian Ocean trade networks (Pion and Gratuze, 2016).Recent archaeological excavations have also contributed significantly to our understanding of key port sites and their role in facilitating long-distance connections. Boussac's work at the Red Sea port of Berenike has revealed a wealth of information about the nature of Roman trade with India and beyond (Boussac, 2020). Similarly, Carswell's investigations at Mantai in Sri Lanka have provided crucial evidence for the island's role as a major entrepôt in Indian Ocean trade networks (Carswell, 2013).The study of shipwrecks has offered unique insights into the material culture of maritime trade. Ray's analysis of the Godavaya shipwreck off the southern coast of Sri Lanka has provided valuable information about the types of goods transported and the technologies employed in ancient Indian Ocean seafaring (Ray, 2018). This research complements the work of Tripati on ancient Indian shipbuilding traditions, offering a more comprehensive understanding of maritime technologies in the region (Tripati, 2017).Numismatic evidence has also played a crucial role in elucidating long-distance connections. Darley's study of Roman coins in India has challenged traditional narratives about the nature and extent of Roman-Indian trade, suggesting more complex patterns of exchange and circulation (Darley, 2015). This work has been complemented by Jansari's research on Kushan coinage, which has shed light on the economic and cultural connections between Central Asia, South Asia, and the Indian Ocean world (Jansari, 2018).The integration of multiple lines of evidence has been a hallmark of recent scholarship on Indian Ocean connections. Beaujard's comprehensive synthesis of archaeological, historical, and linguistic data has provided a holistic view of the development of Indian Ocean world-systems from ancient times to the medieval period (Beaujard, 2019). This interdisciplinary approach has been further exemplified by Seland's work on the 'Periplus of the Erythraean Sea,' which combines textual analysis with archaeological evidence to reconstruct ancient Indian Ocean trade networks (Seland, 2010).In conclusion, recent archaeological research has significantly advanced our understanding of long-distance connections across the ancient Indian Ocean. The application of new scientific techniques, the discovery of new archaeological sites, and the reinterpretation of existing evidence have all contributed to a more nuanced and complex picture of maritime interactions in this region. Future research will undoubtedly continue to refine and expand our knowledge of these fascinating networks of exchange and cultural interaction.
